image.caption: Collection of the U.S. House of Representatives

profileText: A Representative from Kentucky; born in Frankfort, Franklin County, Ky., June 7, 1801; pursued classical studies in Virginia; studied law; was admitted to the bar and commenced practice in Versailles, Ky., in 1828; member of the State house of representatives 1832-1836, 1838, 1839, and 1854; moved to Louisville in 1833; unsuccessful candidate for election in 1836 to the Twenty-fifth Congress; elected as a Whig to the Twenty-seventh Congress (March 4, 1841-March 3, 1843); unsuccessful candidate for reelection in 1842 to the Twenty-eighth Congress; served in the Mexican War as captain of Volunteers; moved to Chicago, Ill., in 1856; returned to Kentucky and engaged in the practice of law until his death near Versailles, Ky., September 22, 1864; interment in State Cemetery, Frankfort, Ky.

creativeWork.freeFormCitationText: Marshall, Thomas Francis. An address on the life and character of the late Richard H. Menefee: delivered before the Law Society of Transylvania University, in the chapel of Morrison College in Lexington, April 12th, 1841. Lexington, Ky.: N.L. & J.W. Finnell, Printers, 1841.
------. Speech of Hon. Thos. F. Marshall, in opposition to the principles of the Know-nothing organization. [Versailles, Ky.: N.p., 1855].

------. Speech of Mr. Marshall, of Kentucky, on the bill to appropriate the proceeds of the sales of the public lands, and to grant pre-emption rights. Delivered in the House of Representatives ... July 6, 1841. Washington: Printed at the National Intelligencer Office, 1841.
------. Speeches and writings of Hon. Thomas F. Marshall. Edited by W. L. Barre. Cincinnati: Applegate & Company, 1858.

------. Speeches of Thomas F. Marshall, of Kentucky, on the resolutions to censure John Q. Adams, delivered in the House of Representatives of the U. S., January 25, 26, and 28, 1842. Washington: Printed by Blair & Rives, 1842.
------. Substance of an address on temperance, delivered before City Hose Company No. XXXIII. New-York: J. B. Swain, printer, 1842.
Shipman, Paul R. A Handful of Bitter Herbs; Reminiscences of Thomas Francis Marshall, 1801-1964, Great Kentucky Orator. Lexington, Ky.: Bluegrass Books, 1953.

researchRecord.name: In the Miscellaneous Manuscripts Collection, 1843, 1 item.
1858, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A letter from Thomas F. Marshall to an unknown recipient written on April 17, 1858. In the letter, Thomas F. Marshall regrets that he cannot be in New York in May but will be there in June. He also mentions that he has no intention of joining the Temperance Union and that he delivers discourses on historical subjects. A finding aid is available in the library.
